caption: We came to see an exhibit about fragrances and the history of them. It was such a unique and immersive experience! The building is also beautiful so be sure to give yourself time to roam.

The building alone is worth the visit. The temporary exhibitions (Palestine, Jean Genet) were brilliant, with lots of information to read.  It seems both exhibitions were mixed with the permanent ones. With signage not always clear (should we take the stairs or lift...), it was sometimes confusing. Not a problem since everything was great, but a bit annoying at times.  The bookstore has lots of choices to deepen the subjects...

Really liked the temporary exhibitions, especially the one about Samarkand textiles and jewelry. The permanent exhibition seems to have interesting exhibits, but lack storyline or proper explanations, so it's not as educational and enjoyable as it could have been.

The name of the building is L'Institut du Monde Arabe. It is an extraordinary edifice by architect Jean Nouvel.  The exhibitions inside and outside are thrilling and exceptional. The store is filled with a wide range of books of poetry, protest images in Iran, Persepolis, novels, and catalogues. You will also find an array of glass ware and ceramics for kitchen and dining , as well as jewellery. One exhibition concerns Palestine with a video of Mamoud Darwich reading his poetry, works of Jean Genet and artworks on loan from the Museum of Palestine located in east Jerusalem. Another exhibit concerns Perfume with actual scents to inhale, as well as a sensual womanist video with haunting V O of intimate scenes in a hamam.

Overall a great place to be as there‚Äôs plenty of history there like the ancient sculpture of god ‚ÄúAl-Lat‚Äù (Photo attached). You can also view Paris from the top of this building which is free to access but the view is not as good as from Montmartre. The architecture of the building is very interesting because there are metallic motifs on the building making a facade (inspired from Arab culture) that move like a camera‚Äôs diaphragm to control the amount of light coming in. Plus, you gotta be very careful once inside specially near the open artefacts, art pieces and installations.

Never go here! They are RACISTS! Horrible experience. Staffs in the front desk and restaurant are very RUDE. They refused us to enter! I‚Äôm Asian and my friend has white skin. When we arrived at 1:50pm (the website shows it close at 2:30pm), the white male staff told us they were full. However, it didn‚Äôt! The website showed we could even reserve for 2:00 and 2:15! We went to the ground floor and told the front desk what happened. They were extremely RUDE!! At first they even said it didn‚Äôt relate them, go ask the restaurant! After I explained that the whole institution should communicate to make sure all the visitors have nice experience, and the staffs in the restaurant are RACISTS, she simply said yes contemptuously without helping anything. I really regret that I‚Äôve paid for the tickets, visited the exhibitions, bought many souvenirs! Terrible racist institution! Don‚Äôt go!

Quite an amazing institution for anyone interested in discovering the greatness and splendor of the classical Arab World as well as the mystery of the Orient. Visited on the occasion of the Al-'Ul√¢ exhibition, where one learns about the rich history of the Arabic peninsula.  On 28-MAY-2024 visited the extraordinary exhibition on the work of French, Algerian-at-heart, painter Etienne Dinet. Absolutely stunning work and excellent exhibition.

A beautiful exhibition ‚ÄúOn the roads of Samarkand, marvels of silk and gold.‚Äù A unique exhibits of hundreds of pieces of splendour crafting, around the 20th century. for the first time shown outside museums in Uzbekistan. Glad I didn‚Äôt miss it.

A very nice place to visit while in Paris, to know a bit about the arabic culture, tradition and some other things from that part of the world! the architecture of the building is wonderful, a mixture between the arabic one and the modern one, really a great mixture, the facade of glass reflecting the sun's rays and allowing to it to light the rooms, no need to electricity!

Very rare and courageous exhibition about LGBTQI+ at the Arab World Institute that shows a set of various young international artists who decided to represent their vision of the Gay world. The exhibition at the IMA are always very well documented and you will learn a lot what ever you will see.
The place is well worth the visit and the roof top restaurant is amazing

The architecture of the building is very interesting, with Arabic geometric motifs all around. And you could take the lift to the 9th floor to have a panoramic view of the Seine and the Notre-Dame, for free! Good for a quick visit if you are not interested in the exhibitions inside the Centre.

Interesting facade for those interested in architecture. I believe interesting exhibitions, however unfortunately I haven't seen them. But nice view from the top (free entrance as of 2021) over Notre Dame and part of Paris.

L‚Äôinstitut du Monde Arab has clearly had better days :-( maintenance is clearly an issue, the upper deck has not been cleaned for ages, cigarettes buts everywhere, well do not take the stairs‚Ä¶ they are rather dirty‚Ä¶. So long‚Ä¶. Very disappointing, the store even more so‚Ä¶ the elevator lettering has had better days‚Ä¶ while the entry tickets are not that cheap but that is not the issue‚Ä¶.
Unique institution: a library open to all visitors, exhibition space, gift shop, restaurant.

Customer experience üíôüíôüíô Service üíôüíôüíô Location üíôüíôüíô Very good museum about arabic art and history with temporary and permanent collections. You can also enjoy the rooftop on top of the building

This was when I first saw Zaha Hadid's work, and I can't help but fall in love with it ever since.  ‚ÄúThere are 360 degrees, so why stick to one?‚Äù  ‚ÄúI have always appreciated those who dare to experiment with materials and proportions.‚Äù  ‚ÄúYou really have to have a goal. The goal posts might shift, but you should have a goal. Know what it is you want to find out.‚Äù
Didn‚Äôt get in to the display. I was there just for the building. And it looked great. You can take the elevator to the top floor for free, and walk along the inside of the buildings shell

One of my favourite places in Paris. The architecture is another great work of Jean Nouvel with the famous mousharabiya on its fa√ßade It has always very rich exhibitions from the arab and islamic world. The terrace has a breathtaking view of Paris and Notre Dame. Noura the Lebanese restaurant on the last floor is always a good idea if you are craving taboul√© and kebb√© Highly recommended
Great architecture and exhibitions. Nice views from rooftop terrasse.
We enjoyed the visit, and you can go to the rooftop to have look over the Paris. Also the most beautiful toilets in a public space :)
The free entry to the top is great, it gives you the best view of the Notre Dame. Sadly I hadn't had enough time to check the entire place out but from what I can tell it's definitely worth visiting.
Beautiful grounds and exposition. A great place to gain more cultural knowledge.

The staff here just showed me the Arab hospitality. They gave me such a detailed intro of the building and where everything is. The rooftop view is amazing (it looks like a restaurant but visitors can pass by) the exhibition is sadly a bit rundown, I wish they could get more funding

institut du monde arabe (The Arab World Institute) - is an organization founded in Paris in 1980 by 18 Arab countries with France to research and share information about the Arab world and its cultural and spiritual values.
Very bad organization, and people are very rude like they do not like non religious people, not recommend rather visit a local museum

Not nearly as interesting as it used to be 20 years ago. A lot of the explanation and background has changed, it used to lead you through the history and development of trade and mathematics and writing and religion, but now seems to lean heavily on contemporary politics without again explaining some of the landscape. Level -2 in particular misses out on the chance to explain the division. Still possibly worth a visit and some of the photography is very thought provoking. But seems to have lost some of it's now basic educational aspects. Very random. You head to the 9th floor for the view for free if you like.

Really nice and interesting place. Helped me understand a lot about Muslims and Arab countries. Really nice and interesting videos too. The permanent exposition is free for less than 26 years old. And the biotique is really nice and big with great products at a relatively low price!  I would recommend anyone to go with someone who knows about Arabic culture so they can further explain and clear doubts if you have any
such a lovely place.  only remark is that some things should be in English too.
Interesting exhibition, the provided information could be more detailed.
A work of art. Stupendous architecture and a wealth of interesting knowledge. It has peaceful and serene environment but I mostly love the garden for tea and food.
Nice library/museum on the Arab world, with a beautiful view on the rooftop.

The main exhibition was disappointingly generic and chaotic. Only a few main descriptions are in English, rest only in french. I had really high hopes to learn something new about this rich and complex word but I didn't. Just very general, boring statements accompanied with poor collection, with no story or explanation behind. Moreover, the building is very dirty and badly organized.

Beautiful buildings. I saw Samarcande, Baya and Habibi. They're short, very interesting, very different exhibitions. In 5 hours you'll spend a nice day at the museum. The food is correct. Going to the bathroom is more tricky, very unusual for a museum.
Very interesting

I was really looking forward to visiting here, and was disappointed. We visited the two special exhibitions (each concerning Algeria, to mark 60 years) and the main exhibition. All felt low on information, and I felt I learned nothing new. The information provided was superficial, at the level I would expect from a geography or religious study textbook targeting children. The display of information was frustrating (Often yellow text on white background, poorly lit and at knee height, or else dark text on a clear background which was hard to read and obscured the objects). It would be great to see a group of visionary curators turn this interesting space into a real opportunity to educate and surprise.

This is a comprehensive museum about the origins of Islam, as well as Judaism and Christianity. The museum has excellent temporary exhibits from showcasing an original Oriental Express train to Hip Hop. The architecture of the building is both striking and functional. The mechanical plates on the windows are mechanized to let in specific amounts of light based on either the user or the general audience. This is also one of the hidden rooftops in Paris that you can get a good view of the city, and it's free! Just take the elevator up to the top floor. To see the rest of the museum you need to pay the entrance fee, but it's worth it. There is also a very nice restaurant on the top floor to enjoy lunch or dinner.

Excellent exhibition, but a very poor museum experience. From the long and inefficient line at the entrance, the antipathetic staff, there was no place to leave the coat-it was full..... & The cafeteria was terrible.
